Harvey Lyman Company
Walnut Grove Facility

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.	FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY

The owners, management, and employees of the Harvey Lyman Company, A Division of The Lyman Group, Inc. (Lyman or TLG), Walnut Grove Facility (Facility) at 14301 Railroad Avenue, Walnut Grove, California 95690 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or regulated pesticides. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Consolidated Emergency Response / Contingency Plan has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.

2.	FACILITY INFORMATION

The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Delta Area of Northern California.

Anhydrous ammonia  is received, stored, and distributed for direct application for crop production nutrients. Regulated pesticides is received, stored, and distributed for direct application in pest control.

Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in a single 14,323-gallon storage tank  (bullet) at the site. The maximum quantity  of anhydrous ammonia handled in this process is 62,580 pounds.

Three regulated pesticides are received by truck, handled by forklift and stored in the warehouse at the site. The maximum quantity of regulated pesticides stored at the Facility is 17,496 pounds.

3.	THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes.

4.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.

7.	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia and regulated pesticides processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.

e latest review of maintenance procedures was conducted on November 20, 2015.

RMP Change Management:  Operation, safety, and environmental issues must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety and integrity of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The Facility RMP Change Management (RMPCM) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures.

Pre-startup Review:  The pre-startup review applies to additions or modifications to the Anhydrous Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated. Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a pre-startup safety review. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the RMPCM review. Additionally, a pre-startup safety review is performed in conjunction with the RMPCM review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety information.
 
Compliance Audits:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. The most recent compliance audit was conducted in March 2016. 

Incident Investigation:  Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident.

Employee Participation:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Facility has implemented procedures regarding employee participation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all a

pplicable areas of the prevention program.

Hot Work Permit:  Hot work does not typically occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process. However, should hot work be required, Lyman has developed a written Hot Work Permit to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements.

Contractor Safety:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Walnut Grove Facility. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia. 
In addition to the prevention program elements described above, the following chemical-specific prevention steps have been implemented.

Anhydrous Ammonia:  The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines and regulations

- California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Division 1, Chapter 4, Subchapter 1, Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders; 
- Compressed Gas Association (CGA) Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, CGA 2.1-2014 edition [previously American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI) K61.1, 1999 ed.]; and
- United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.
Regulated Pesticides:  The Facility implements provisions of the National Fire Protection Association and Uniform Fire Code for the storage of pesticides at the Facility. 

5.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or regulated pesticides during the last five years resulting in death, injury, an evacuation, sheltering in place, or property or environmental damage.

6.	THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.9
